newsitem.title: SWITZERLAND: Referendum shadow falls over Swiss Holocaust fund.
newsitem.headline: Referendum shadow falls over Swiss Holocaust fund.

text.p: Swiss hopes of repairing the country's battered image after months of fueding with world Jewish groups could be put in jeopardy by far-right threats to seek a national referendum on whether Berne should pay into a Holocaust survivors fund.
Political analysts agreed on Thursday there was potential for a "no" vote based on a deep-seated Swiss mistrust of the outside world.
But they questioned whether rightist politicians were willing to be stamped as anti-semitic for campaigning against Berne contributing to the fund, which is starting on March 1 with bank donations.

At issue is a threat by Christoph Blocher, an industrialist and right-wing member of parliament, to call a referendum if the federal government contributes to the aid fund for impoverished Holocaust survivors.

"Blocher wants to make use of the fact that a big part of the population is fed up with the Holocaust debate and that many people are annoyed by the accusations of someone like U.S. Senator Alfonse D'Amato," the newspaper Berner Zeitung commented.

World Jewish groups and other critics, including New York Republican D'Amato, have accused Swiss banks of sitting on accounts left by victims of Nazi genocide and the country as a whole of profiting cynically from its neutral status in World War Two.

Berne politicians say the government is wary of a popular backlash that could sink its effort to restore Switzerland's tarnished humanitarian image by having the government join in the financial goodwill gesture.
"It would be more than a catastrophe," one official close to the government's damage control efforts said.

Blocher made his threat on Wednesday, the same day the cabinet agreed to administer the Holocaust fund as a gesture of atonement after months of mounting conflict with the World Jewish Congress (WJC) that threatened to damage Switzerland's key banking sector.

The fund will start with 100 million Swiss francs ($68 million) donated by the three biggest Swiss banks and is expected to grow with more corporate donations, but Berne has delayed a decision on joining while it grooms broad political support for the step.
"When the issue is taxpayers' money for foreign organisations, it is very hard to get support in a referendum," Hans Hirter of the Institute for Political Science in Berne said.

"On the other hand, and this is what militates against a referendum, the right-wing and conservatives have reservations about a campaign against the fund because it could be stamped as anti-Jewish," he told Reuters.
The Zurich daily Tages-Anzeiger, on the biggest Swiss papers, brushed aside concern about a ballot box defeat and challenged rightists to seek a show-down.
"There is no doubt that a clear majority of the people would decide in favour of a well organised foundation for Holocaust victims," it wrote.
Still, Hirter noted the federal government has been hit by popular rejection of many of its major policy initiatives in referendums in the past decade.
Swiss voters in 1986 rejected joining the United Nations, cancelled plans in 1992 to join the European Economic Area free-trade zone and in 1994 blocked a Swiss "blue helmet" U.N. peacekeeping role.
On the other hand, Swiss voters in 1994 also approved a government plan to introduce a law against racism.
Under Swiss direct democracy, a binding referendum can be forced by gathering 50,000 signatures.
Blocher, from the Swiss People's Party (SVP) that is on the far right of Berne's four-party centre-right coalition government, was a leader of the campaigns against U.N. and EU ties.
($ = 1.477 Swiss Francs)
